summary: This is a consent order between the New York State Department of Financial Services (DFS) and Deutsche Bank AG, resolving an investigation into Deutsche Bank's anti-money laundering (AML) compliance failures. The investigation focused on three high-risk relationships: the bank's direct relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and his entities, and its correspondent banking relationships with FBME and Danske Estonia. The order details systemic failures in due diligence, transaction monitoring, and risk management, resulting in a $150 million penalty.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy financier and convicted sex offender who maintained accounts at Deutsche Bank from 2013 to 2018. The document details how the bank onboarded and maintained his accounts despite his criminal history and numerous red flags.

persons.name: RELATIONSHIP MANAGER-1
persons.context: Former employee of US BANK-1 who joined Deutsche Bank and initiated the Epstein relationship, advocating for it as lucrative. Prepared and sent the initial onboarding memorandum.

persons.name: EXECUTIVE-1
persons.context: Senior Deutsche Bank executive who approved the Epstein relationship via an email, bypassing formal reputational risk review. Later met with Epstein in person in 2015.

persons.name: EXECUTIVE-2
persons.role: Chief Operating Officer of Wealth Management Americas
persons.context: Senior Deutsche Bank executive who received the initial Epstein onboarding memorandum and later agreed to escalate the relationship to the ARRC in 2015.

persons.name: RELATIONSHIP COORDINATOR-1
persons.context: Prepared the initial onboarding memorandum for Jeffrey Epstein. Handled inquiries about beneficiaries of the Butterfly Trust.

persons.name: AML OFFICER-1
persons.context: Identified new negative press about Epstein in 2015 and advocated for re-escalation despite the prior approval.

persons.name: AML OFFICER-2
persons.context: Key compliance officer involved in the 2015 ARRC review of Epstein. Misinterpreted the ARRC's conditions, leading to inadequate transaction monitoring.

persons.name: COVERAGE TEAM MEMBER-1
persons.context: Escalated Epstein's requests for increased trading limits and new account openings to compliance.

persons.name: ACCOUNTANT-1
persons.context: Represented Epstein in communications with Deutsche Bank, including requests to open accounts for his charity.

persons.name: RELATIONSHIP MANAGER-2
persons.context: Replaced RELATIONSHIP MANAGER-1 in handling Epstein's accounts. Was not informed of the ARRC's conditions and later drafted reference letters for Epstein.

persons.name: ATTORNEY-1
persons.context: Authorized user on Epstein's accounts who made frequent cash withdrawals, prompting structuring concerns. Provided explanations for the cash use.

persons.name: AML COMPLIANCE DIRECTOR-1
persons.role: Former Director of U.S. Anti-Financial Crimes
persons.context: Key Deutsche Bank compliance official involved in the FBME and Danske Estonia relationships. Conducted meetings, training, and drafted internal memos advocating for risk mitigation or closure.

persons.name: Linda A. Lacewell
persons.context: Signed the consent order on behalf of the New York State Department of Financial Services.

persons.name: Joe Salama
persons.role: Global Head of Litigation and Regulatory Enforcement
persons.context: Signed the consent order on behalf of Deutsche Bank AG, its New York Branch, and Deutsche Bank Trust Company of the Americas.

persons.name: Andrew Stemmer
persons.role: Head of Litigation & Regulatory Enforcement - Americas
persons.context: Signed the consent order on behalf of Deutsche Bank AG, its New York Branch, and Deutsche Bank Trust Company of the Americas.

connections.description: RELATIONSHIP MANAGER-1, who had previously serviced Epstein at another bank, recruited him to Deutsche Bank and managed his accounts.
EXECUTIVE-1 provided the initial approval for onboarding Epstein and later conducted a due diligence meeting with him at his home.
ATTORNEY-1 was Epstein's personal attorney with authority to conduct transactions, including frequent cash withdrawals, on his behalf.
RELATIONSHIP MANAGER-1 reported to and sought approval from EXECUTIVE-1 for the Epstein relationship.
AML OFFICER-2 escalated concerns about the Epstein relationship to EXECUTIVE-2, who agreed to bring it before the ARRC.

events.title: Initial Public Allegations Against Epstein
events.description: Press reports first accuse Jeffrey Epstein of paying a 14-year-old girl for a 'massage'.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Investigation
events.description: Palm Beach Police Department commences an investigation into Epstein, uncovering dozens of alleged victims.

events.title: Epstein's Plea Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pleads guilty to two state prostitution charges (including solicitation of a minor) in exchange for a deferred prosecution agreement on federal sex-trafficking charges. He serves 13 months in jail.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Unsealed
events.description: Epstein's 2008 non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. DOJ is made public in connection with civil suits by alleged victims.

events.title: Deutsche Bank Onboards Epstein
events.description: Deutsche Bank officially opens its first accounts for Epstein-related entities (Southern Trust Company Inc. and Southern Financial LLC), initiating the banking relationship.

events.title: ARRC Review of Epstein Relationship
events.description: Deutsche Bank's Americas Reputational Risk Committee (ARRC) meets to discuss the Epstein relationship but keeps no minutes. They decide to continue the relationship with conditions.

events.title: Deutsche Bank Terminates Epstein
events.description: Following a November 2018 Miami Herald article, Deutsche Bank informs Epstein it will no longer service his accounts.

events.title: FinCEN 311 Designation for FBME
events.description: The U.S. Treasury's FinCEN names FBME a foreign financial institution of primary money laundering concern.

events.title: DFS Consent Order Signed
events.description: The New York State Department of Financial Services and Deutsche Bank sign this consent order, imposing a $150 million penalty.

keyFacts: Deutsche Bank maintained a banking relationship for Jeffrey Epstein from August 2013 to December 2018 despite his 2008 guilty plea for soliciting a minor for prostitution and widespread public allegations of sex trafficking.

The bank processed over $2.65 million in wires from Epstein's accounts to alleged co-conspirators and women with Eastern European surnames, and over $800,000 in structured cash withdrawals by his attorney, with minimal effective scrutiny.
Deutsche Bank's initial approval of Epstein was based on an informal email from a senior executive (EXECUTIVE-1), bypassing the formal reputational risk committee review required by policy.

The bank also failed to adequately manage high-risk correspondent banking relationships with FBME (facilitating over $618 billion in transactions) and Danske Estonia (facilitating over $267 billion), despite numerous suspicious transactions and known AML deficiencies.

The New York State Department of Financial Services imposed a $150 million penalty on Deutsche Bank for these systemic AML compliance failures and for conducting business in an unsafe and unsound manner.
